references: Recently, the works [17, 18] proposed to utilize hybrid momentum gradient estimators [7, 8]. The MIME algorithm [17] matched the optimal sample complexity (under certain smoothness assumptions) of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’3/2)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) of the centralized non-convex stochastic optimization algorithms [5, 6, 7, 8]. Similarly, Fed-GLOMO [18] achieved the same sample complexity while employing compression to further reduce communication. Both MIME and Fed-GLOMO required ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’3/2)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) communication rounds to achieve an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-stationary solution. Please see Table 1 for a summary of the above discussion.

Theorem 3.1 suggests that when Iğ¼I and bğ‘b are selected appropriately, then STEMÂ achieves ğ’ª~â€‹(Ïµâˆ’3/2)~ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ32\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) and ğ’ª~â€‹(Ïµâˆ’1)~ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ1\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\epsilon^{-1}) sample and communication complexities. Taking them separately, these complexity bounds are the best achievable by the existing FL algorithms (upto logarithmic factors regardless of sample or batch Lipschitz smooth assumption) [35]; see Table 1. We note that the ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’3/2)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ32\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-3/2}) complexity is the best possible that can be achieved by centralized SGD with the sample Lipschitz gradient assumption; see [5]. On the other hand, the ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’1)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-1}) complexity bound is also likely to be the optimal, since in [9] the authors showed that even when the local steps use a class of (deterministic) first-order algorithms, ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµâˆ’1)ğ’ªsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-1}) is the best achievable communication complexity. The only difference is that [9] does not explicitly assume the intra-node variance bound (i.e., the second relation in Assumption 2-(ii)). We leave the precise characterization of the communication lower bound with intra-node variance as future work. âˆ

Note that the requirement on Tğ‘‡T being lower bounded is only relevant for theoretical purposes, a similar requirement was also imposed in [14] to prove convergence.

u\in[0,1] in the statement of Theorem 3.2 balances Iğ¼I and bğ‘b at each WN while maintaining state-of-the-art sample and communication complexities; please see Table 1 for a comparison of those bounds with existing FedAvg bounds.

u=1, FedAvg (cf. Theorem 3.2) reduces to FedAvg proposed in [12, 14] and for Î½=0ğœˆ0
u=0, the algorithm can be viewed as a large batch FedAvg with constant local updates [15, 16]. Note that similar to STEM, it is known that for I=1ğ¼1I=1, the Minibatch SGDâ€™s performance is independent of the heterogeneity parameter, Î¶ğœ\zeta [13]. We also point out that if Algorithm 1 uses Nesterovâ€™s or Polyakâ€™s momentum [14] at local WNs instead of the recursive momentum estimator we get the same guarantees as in Theorem 3.2.
